SEARCH
Module org.jandle
Package org.jandle.api

Class JandleApplication

java.lang.Object
org.jandle.api.JandleApplication
All Implemented Interfaces:
HttpHandler
public class JandleApplication extends Object implements HttpHandler
Core entry point of the Jandle HTTP framework.

JandleApplication is responsible for:

  • Registering HTTP handlers and filters
  • Routing incoming requests to matching handlers
  • Constructing HttpRequest and HttpResponse objects
  • Executing the filter chain and handler
  • Handling framework-level errors

This class implements HttpHandler and is intended to be registered directly with HttpServer.

HttpRequest lifecycle:

  1. handle(HttpExchange) is invoked by the HTTP server
  2. The request method and path are resolved
  3. A matching route is searched
  4. HttpRequest and HttpResponse are created
  5. A FilterChain of filters is executed
  6. The final Handler handles the request

  • Method Details

    • handle

      public void handle(HttpExchange exchange) throws IOException
      Entry point for all incoming HTTP requests.

      This method:

      • Resolves the HTTP method
      • Searches for a matching handler
      • Executes the filter chain
      • Handles framework-level errors
      Specified by:
      handle in interface HttpHandler
      Throws:
      IOException

    • registerHandler

      public void registerHandler(Handler handler, Filter... filters) throws InvocationTargetException, NoSuchMethodException, InstantiationException, IllegalAccessException
      Registers a handler and associates it with its route and filters.

      Filters declared via annotations on the handler class (e.g. @HttpRequestFilters) are used by default.

      If no filters are explicitly provided, the filters defined by annotations are instantiated and applied automatically.

      If filter instances are provided to this method, they are used instead of creating new instances via reflection. This allows filters to:

      • Use parameterized constructors
      • Receive external configuration or dependencies
      • Share state between handlers if desired
      Parameters:
      handler - the handler instance to register
      filters - optional filter instances; if empty, annotation-declared filters are used
      Throws:
      InvocationTargetException - if reflective instantiation fails
      NoSuchMethodException - if a required constructor is missing
      InstantiationException - if a filter or handler cannot be instantiated
      IllegalAccessException - if a constructor is not accessible

    • registerHandlers

      public void registerHandlers(Handler... handlers) throws InvocationTargetException, NoSuchMethodException, InstantiationException, IllegalAccessException
      Registers multiple handlers using their annotation-defined configuration.

      Each handler is processed exactly as if registerHandler(Handler, Filter...) were called individually with no explicitly provided filters.

      This means:

      • Routing information (path and HTTP method) is resolved from annotations
      • Filters declared via annotations are instantiated and applied
      • Global filters are automatically prepended

      This method is best suited for simple use cases where filters:

      • Have no constructor parameters
      • Do not require external configuration
      • Can be safely instantiated via reflection

      For handlers that require filters with parameterized constructors or externally managed dependencies, use registerHandler(Handler, Filter...) and provide filter instances explicitly.

      Parameters:
      handlers - one or more handler instances to register
      Throws:
      InvocationTargetException - if reflective instantiation of a handler or its filters fails
      NoSuchMethodException - if a required constructor is missing
      InstantiationException - if a handler or filter cannot be instantiated
      IllegalAccessException - if a constructor is not accessible

    • setGlobalFilters

      public void setGlobalFilters(Filter... globalFilters)
      Sets filters that are applied to all handlers.
      Parameters:
      globalFilters - filters to apply to all handlers

    • getExecutor

      public Executor getExecutor()
      Returns the executor.
      Returns:
      the Executor established for this server or null if not set

    • setExecutor

      public void setExecutor(Executor executor)
      Sets the executor used by the underlying HTTP server. Defaults to null
      Parameters:
      executor - the Executor to set or null to use the default implementation

    • start

      public void start()
      Starts the HTTP server using the configured settings.

      This method:

      • Registers this application as the root HttpHandler
      • Applies the configured Executor, if any
      • Starts the underlying HttpServer

      This overload does not register a startup callback. To execute custom logic after the server has started, use start(OnServerStart).

    • start

      public void start(OnServerStart cb)
      Starts the HTTP server and optionally executes a callback after startup.

      The provided callback is invoked after the server has successfully started and is ready to accept requests.

      Typical use cases include:

      • Logging startup information
      • Initializing background tasks
      • Registering external resources
      Parameters:
      cb - optional startup callback executed after the server starts; may be null

    • stop

      public void stop(int delay)
      Stops the HTTP server after a given delay.

      The delay allows in-flight exchanges to complete before the server is fully shut down.

      This overload does not execute a cleanup callback. To perform cleanup logic before shutdown, use stop(int, CleanupCallback).

      Parameters:
      delay - delay in seconds before the server is stopped

    • stop

      public void stop(int delay, CleanupCallback cb)
      Stops the HTTP server after a given delay and optionally executes a cleanup callback.

      The callback is executed before the underlying HttpServer is stopped.

      Typical use cases include:

      • Releasing resources
      • Flushing logs
      • Gracefully shutting down background tasks
      Parameters:
      delay - delay in seconds before the server is stopped
      cb - optional cleanup callback executed before stopping; may be null

    • setLogger

      public void setLogger(JandleLogger logger)
      Sets a custom logger.
      Parameters:
      logger - custom JandleLogger logger. If null is set the default TraceLogger logger is used.

    • cleanup

      public void cleanup(CleanupCallback cb)
      Executes the provided cleanup callback.
      Parameters:
      cb - cleanup callback to execute
